attributes.action: urge the broadcasting regulator OFCOM to tighten the rules over the possible identification of children whose parents feature in DNA paternity test TV programmes such as “The Jeremy Kyle Show”.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
ITV says its current policy “is that no children of school age are the subject of DNA tests and particular care is taken in relation to children of pre-school age, with children over the age of 18 months being involved only in exceptional cases”.

This means that programmes such as “The Jeremy Kyle Show” subject babies up to the age of 18 months (as well as older children in “exceptional cases”) to paternity tests on daytime television.  By identifying the parents, the broadcaster is identifying the children involved.

This could lead to huge problems for these children.  Their parents' arguments and the DNA testing on TV make them a matter of public record.  The chances of the children discovering what happened are high.  Others can remember the programme or have recorded it leading to bullying or humiliation for the child.

An example of this kind of Jeremy Kyle Show was titled “Brother, I’ll Prove I’m the Father of Your Ex-Girlfriend’s Baby”.

OFCOM must tighten its guidelines so NO young people of any age can be identified from such programmes.

rejection.details: This is a matter for direct communication with Ofcom.
reasons: Issues for which an e-petition is not the appropriate channel
